unit_title: First Law of Thermodynamics: Energy Conservation in Thermodynamics
subject: Physics
expanded_description: Comprehensive study of the First Law of Thermodynamics as the principle of energy conservation applied to thermal systems. Covers internal energy, work, heat transfer, and applications to various thermodynamic processes.
learning_objectives: State and explain the First Law of Thermodynamics
Calculate work done in thermodynamic processes
Analyze energy transfers in different thermodynamic systems
Apply the First Law to various thermodynamic processes
Solve problems involving internal energy, work, and heat

core_concept.principle: The First Law of Thermodynamics states that the change in internal energy of a system equals the heat added to the system minus the work done by the system: $\Delta U = Q - W$. This represents energy conservation, where internal energy ($U$) is the total microscopic energy, heat ($Q$) is energy transfer due to temperature difference, and work ($W$) is energy transfer by mechanical means.
core_concept.explanation: The First Law establishes that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only converted between different forms. It provides the fundamental framework for analyzing energy transformations in thermal systems, from simple heating to complex engines.

image.caption: The First Law balances internal energy changes with heat input and work output

sections.introduction: The First Law of Thermodynamics provides the mathematical foundation for energy accounting in thermal systems. Understanding its components and sign conventions is essential for analyzing energy transformations.

image.alt: Historical development and modern applications of the First Law
image.caption: From early heat engines to modern power systems, the First Law governs energy transformations

key_concept.definition: The First Law: $\Delta U = Q - W$, where $\Delta U$ is change in internal energy, $Q$ is net heat transfer into the system, and $W$ is work done by the system. Internal energy ($U$) includes kinetic and potential energy of all molecules. Heat ($Q$) is positive when entering the system. Work ($W$) is positive when done by the system on surroundings.
key_concept.context: This law explains why perpetual motion machines are impossible, governs engine operation, and provides the basis for energy efficiency calculations in all thermal systems.

image.alt: Components of the First Law equation
image.caption: The First Law relates internal energy changes to heat and work transfers

classifications.value: Classification of systems based on energy and matter exchange
characteristics: Isolated system: no energy or matter exchange ($Q=0$, $W=0$, $\Delta U=0$)
Closed system: energy exchange but no matter exchange
Open system: both energy and matter exchange
classifications.behavior: Each system type has specific constraints that simplify the First Law application and determine how energy transformations occur

examples.explanation: Most common in basic thermodynamics, where mass is constant but energy transfers occur through heat and work

image.caption: Closed systems exchange energy but not matter with surroundings

examples.explanation: No heat transfer ($Q=0$), so $\Delta U = -W$ - all internal energy changes come from work done

image.caption: Adiabatic processes involve no heat transfer, linking internal energy directly to work

classifications.note: The choice of system boundaries is arbitrary but crucial for correct application of the First Law

principles.statement: For a gas system, work done during volume change is $W = \int P\, dV$. For constant pressure processes: $W = P\Delta V$. For ideal gases, work depends on the process path between initial and final states. The area under the P-V curve represents work done.
principles.application: This principle enables calculation of work in engines, compressors, and expansion processes. It explains why different paths between the same states can produce different amounts of work
principles.example: In isobaric expansion at 200 kPa from 0.1 m³ to 0.3 m³, work done = $200,000 \times (0.3-0.1) = 40,000$ J
principles.analogy: Like climbing different routes up a mountain - the elevation change (internal energy) is the same, but the work done depends on the path taken

image.caption: Work equals the area under the process path on a P-V diagram

worked_examples.title: Basic First Law Application
worked_examples.problem: A system absorbs 500 J of heat and does 300 J of work on its surroundings. Calculate the change in internal energy.

step_by_step.explanation: Heat in: $Q = +500$ J, Work by system: $W = +300$ J

worked_examples.final_answer: Internal energy increases by 200 J. The system gains net energy despite doing work.

image.caption: The First Law balances heat input, work output, and internal energy change

worked_examples.title: Work Calculation in Expansion
worked_examples.problem: A gas expands from 0.2 m³ to 0.5 m³ at constant pressure 150 kPa. Calculate the work done and internal energy change if the system absorbs 80 kJ of heat.
worked_examples.final_answer: Work done = 45 kJ, Internal energy increase = 35 kJ. Part of the heat input goes to work, part to internal energy.

image.caption: Constant pressure expansion work equals pressure times volume change

sections.introduction: The First Law applies to various thermodynamic processes with specific constraints. Analyzing these processes reveals how energy transforms under different conditions and provides insights into practical systems.

image.alt: Different thermodynamic processes on P-V diagrams
image.caption: Various thermodynamic processes follow specific paths with characteristic energy transformations

key_concept.definition: Key thermodynamic processes include: isobaric (constant pressure: $W = P\Delta V$), isochoric (constant volume: $W = 0$, $\Delta U = Q$), isothermal (constant temperature: $\Delta U = 0$ for ideal gases, $Q = W$), and adiabatic (no heat transfer: $Q = 0$, $\Delta U = -W$). Each process has specific work and heat transfer characteristics.
key_concept.context: These idealized processes model real systems like engine cycles, refrigeration systems, and chemical processes. They provide the foundation for understanding more complex thermodynamic behavior.

image.caption: Different thermodynamic processes have characteristic relationships between variables

characteristics: Isothermal: constant temperature, $\Delta U = 0$ for ideal gases
classifications.behavior: Each process follows specific physical constraints that determine how pressure, volume, and temperature relate, and how energy transfers occur

examples.explanation: Constant volume process where all heat input increases internal energy since no work is done ($W=0$, $\Delta U = Q$)

image.caption: Isochoric processes occur at constant volume with no work done

examples.explanation: Constant temperature process where heat input equals work output for ideal gases ($\Delta U=0$, $Q=W$), requiring careful heat transfer to maintain temperature

image.caption: Isothermal processes maintain constant temperature through heat exchange

classifications.note: Real processes often approximate these ideal cases, with deviations due to friction, finite time, and other practical considerations

principles.statement: For ideal gases, internal energy depends only on temperature: $U = \frac{f}{2}nRT$, where $f$ is degrees of freedom (3 for monatomic, 5 for diatomic), $n$ is moles, $R$ is gas constant, and $T$ is absolute temperature. Therefore, $\Delta U = \frac{f}{2}nR\Delta T$ for any process. This simplifies First Law applications for ideal gases.
principles.application: This principle enables calculation of internal energy changes from temperature measurements alone, regardless of the process path. It's fundamental to gas cycle analysis and calorimetry
principles.example: For monatomic ideal gas, $\Delta U = \frac{3}{2}nR\Delta T$. A 2 mole gas heated from 300K to 400K increases internal energy by $\frac{3}{2} \times 2 \times 8.314 \times 100 = 2494$ J
principles.analogy: Like a bank account balance depending only on the total money, not how it's distributed between different currencies

image.caption: Ideal gas internal energy depends only on temperature, not pressure or volume

worked_examples.title: Isochoric Process Analysis
worked_examples.problem: A rigid container holds 0.1 m³ of ideal gas at 200 kPa. 50 kJ of heat is added. Calculate the final pressure if initial temperature was 300 K. (Assume diatomic gas)

step_by_step.explanation: Rigid container means constant volume (isochoric), so $W = 0$
For diatomic gas: $\Delta U = \frac{5}{2}nR\Delta T \rightarrow 50,000 = \frac{5}{2} \times 8.02 \times 8.314 \times \Delta T$

worked_examples.final_answer: Final pressure = 400 kPa. All heat input increases temperature and pressure at constant volume.

image.caption: Isochoric processes convert all heat input into internal energy increase

worked_examples.title: Isothermal Expansion
worked_examples.problem: 2 moles of ideal gas expand isothermally at 400 K from 0.1 m³ to 0.4 m³. Calculate work done and heat transfer.

step_by_step.explanation: $Q = W = 9216$ J (heat input equals work output)

worked_examples.final_answer: Work done = 9.22 kJ, Heat transfer = 9.22 kJ. The gas converts all heat input into work during isothermal expansion.

image.caption: Isothermal processes convert heat directly into work at constant temperature

sections.introduction: The First Law enables analysis of complex thermodynamic cycles used in engines, refrigerators, and power plants. Understanding cycle analysis reveals how continuous energy conversion occurs in practical systems.

image.alt: Thermodynamic cycles in engines and refrigerators
image.caption: Thermodynamic cycles enable continuous energy conversion in practical devices

key_concept.definition: Thermodynamic cycles consist of series of processes that return a system to its initial state. For complete cycles: $\Delta U = 0$, so $Q_{\text{net}} = W_{\text{net}}$. In heat engines: $W_{\text{net}} = Q_H - Q_C$, efficiency $\eta = W/Q_H$. In refrigerators: coefficient of performance $COP = Q_C/W$.
key_concept.context: Cycle analysis explains the operation of internal combustion engines, steam power plants, refrigeration systems, and heat pumps. It provides the basis for energy efficiency improvements in these systems.

image.caption: Thermodynamic cycles have zero net internal energy change over complete cycles

classifications.value: Different types of energy conversion cycles
characteristics: Power cycles (heat engines): convert heat to work
Refrigeration cycles: use work to move heat from cold to hot
Heat pump cycles: use work to move heat into warm space
Carnot cycle: theoretically most efficient reversible cycle
Rankine cycle: steam power plant cycle
classifications.behavior: Each cycle type has specific process sequences designed to optimize particular energy conversion objectives

examples.explanation: Theoretical maximum efficiency cycle consisting of two isothermal and two adiabatic processes: $\eta = 1 - \frac{T_C}{T_H}$

image.caption: Carnot cycle provides the theoretical maximum efficiency for given temperature limits

examples.explanation: Practical refrigeration cycle using evaporation (heat absorption) and compression, with COP typically 2-4 for household refrigerators

image.caption: Refrigeration cycles use work to pump heat from cold to warm regions

classifications.note: Real cycles have lower efficiencies than ideal cycles due to irreversibilities like friction, finite temperature differences, and pressure drops

principles.statement: For any complete thermodynamic cycle, the net work output equals the net heat input: $W_{\text{net}} = Q_{\text{in}} - Q_{\text{out}}$. The system returns to its initial state, so $\Delta U = 0$ over the cycle. This principle prevents perpetual motion machines of the first kind (machines that create energy).
principles.application: This principle enables calculation of engine efficiencies, refrigeration performance, and guides design improvements in energy conversion systems. It sets fundamental limits on what thermodynamic devices can achieve
principles.example: A heat engine absorbing 1000 J from a hot reservoir and rejecting 600 J to a cold reservoir produces 400 J of work with 40% efficiency
principles.analogy: Like a water wheel - the net work output cannot exceed the energy difference between water entering and leaving

image.caption: Complete cycles have zero net internal energy change, balancing heat and work

worked_examples.title: Heat Engine Efficiency
worked_examples.problem: A heat engine absorbs 800 J from a 500 K reservoir and does 300 J of work. Calculate the heat rejected and the efficiency.
worked_examples.final_answer: Heat rejected = 500 J, Efficiency = 37.5%. The engine converts 37.5% of heat input into work.

image.caption: Heat engines convert part of heat input into work, rejecting the remainder

worked_examples.title: Refrigerator Performance
worked_examples.problem: A refrigerator removes 1200 J from a cold space while consuming 400 J of work. Calculate the coefficient of performance and heat rejected to the room.
worked_examples.final_answer: COP = 3, Heat rejected = 1600 J. The refrigerator moves 3 J of heat for each 1 J of work input.

image.caption: Refrigerators use work to move heat from cold to warm regions

common_misconceptions: Thinking heat and work are the same type of energy
Believing internal energy depends on process path
Confusing work done on vs work done by system
Thinking cycles can have net internal energy change
Believing efficiency can exceed Carnot limit
summary: The First Law of Thermodynamics, $\Delta U = Q - W$, expresses energy conservation in thermal systems. Internal energy changes balance heat transfer into the system minus work done by the system. Work in expansion/compression is $W = \int P\, dV$, represented by the area under P-V curves. Key processes include isobaric (constant P), isochoric (constant V), isothermal (constant T), and adiabatic (no heat transfer). For ideal gases, internal energy depends only on temperature. In complete cycles, $\Delta U = 0$ and $Q_{\text{net}} = W_{\text{net}}$. The First Law governs energy transformations in engines, refrigerators, and all thermal systems, preventing perpetual motion and setting fundamental limits on energy conversion efficiency.
